captions.text:
Science. Perhaps man’s greatest
tool in understanding how the world works.
But does it lead us to truth?

German philosopher Freiderich Neitzsche was
an avid science
enthusiast, but he also recognized that even science has its limitations.

See, science touts the ability to
“explain” the world, when according to
Nietzsche, it can only “describe” it.

For example, science might attempt
to explain WHY fire burns by saying it’s

an exothermic combination of a combustible
material with oxygen. That certainly describes

“HOW” fire burns, but it doesn’t address
“why?” As in- why does fire exist the
way that it does?

Although science has allowed us to
describe the world in greater detail, we’re

still completely clueless as to the meaning
behind it all.

As the philosopher who famously
said “God is dead,” it’s obvious that

he isn’t criticizing science in favor of
religion.

But he recognizes this dilemma- Religion attempts
to answer the

question of meaning, but the achievements
of science have cast doubt on such beliefs.

Science may try to fill this void
of meaning, but it can’t. Because as Nietzsche

said “science... has no consideration for
ultimate purposes.”

Problem for Nietzsche is- most
people don’t recognize this limitation,

and instead worship science as a kind of new
religion, an objective value for a godless
age.

Just turn on the television and
you’ll see how science has become evangelized.

Nietzsche dares us to take a step
further- to not only think critically of religion,

but to think critically of knowledge itself.
For worshipping knowledge for knowledge’s
sake can lead to dire consequences.

As he said:” Man shouldn’t be the
servant of knowledge. Knowledge should be
the servant of man.”

title: Does SCIENCE = TRUTH? (Nietzsche + Mega Man) - 8-Bit Philosophy

comments.author: SteVen Cares

comments.text:
Science leads us away from falsehood; it does not lead us to truth.  If you 
understand the philosophy of science and the scientific method, you realize 
that we can only disprove things with science, not 100% prove them.  The 
theories we use to explain the "why" of things are still a pretty artistic 
process.  Anyone with moderate training can look at the data provided by 
post-Einstein experiments and see how they prove some of Newtonian physics 
wrong.  But not just any scientist could have come up with the theory of 
relativity, even if they'd seen all the data available.  The "truth" is 
still just our best educated, creative guesses, unless and until science 
disproves them.﻿

comments.text:
+Shawouin Remember that Nietzsche died in 1900... he wasn't around for the 
Industrial Revolution or the rapid expansion of scientific understanding.

He is speaking from his perspective, and it is still valid today to some 
degree.

He's not saying ignore science...

He's reinforcing what many scientists say...

Science is the How... not the Why.

It's a strange distinction at first glance, but it makes all the difference 
in the world.

WHY do Tigers have sharp teeth?   ... No answer.

HOW do Tigers have sharp teeth?  ... Evolution that adapted the creature to 
hunt and eat flesh.

How is not Why.

People accuse Evolution of explaining the Why.   It does not...

Why is unknowable as it does not exist in the Universe, according to 
Nietzsche.

In order for WHY to exist.. some THINKING being must do something "for a 
reason."

Reasons are subject to Reasoning which is the realm of Consciousness.

Bacteria don't get you sick BECAUSE they want you sick...

They don't want anything.. they just do what they do... no thoughts, no 
feelings.. no "ideas."

They don't "WANT" to get you sick... they exist.. they bump into you.. they 
make you sick.

That's "how"...

"Why" am I sick?

Either SOMEONE would have to purposely get you sick... or you would have to 
infect yourself with PURPOSE.

Then there's a "Why"

Otherwise.. it's just finding out "How."

This is the Existential response to death too.

You WILL die... "Why" doesn't matter... "How" doesn't change the fact that 
you will die.

So... live your life accepting and understanding that it's irrelevant.  ;)

"Why" is only relevant to instances with an intent behind them.

comments.text:
+Gölök Z L F Buday *"Einstein said, Scientific Progress is like a 
pathological criminal with an axe." This is well done. it is a true danger 
(well explained by South Park too, "Science Damn It") people religiously 
follow scientific views, such as even threatening and attacking people who 
want to and attempt to disprove a theory they hold to slavishly.* 

That's a quote mine -- I'll give you the benefit of the doubt that it was 
unintentional. Yet it wasn't a critique of science, but of human 
civilization. Full quote:

*"How is it at all possible that this culture-loving era could be so 
monstrously amoral? More and more I come to value charity and love of one’s 
fellow being above everything else. … All our lauded technological 
progress—our very civilization—is like the axe in the hand of the 
pathological criminal."* -- Albert Einstein

It's also important to note that Einstein wrote this in his early years in 
response to World War 1. This is an argument in favor of scientific 
rationality, not the opposite.

If there's anything to deduce from his quote, it's to end the forces that 
cause conflicts (religious indoctrination and the Just-World fallacy 
commonly associated with it, racism, sexism, etc.), improve education 
(including scientific education), etc. We'll stop behaving like primitive 
beasts with a loaded gun when we educate ourselves and strive to become 
more like Einstein intellectually.

About treating science as an authority, that will also end when you improve 
science education. Then more people will actually *understand* the science 
and possibly even challenge it rather than merely accepting it.

We might not all have an IQ in the 160s, but one way to start is to stop 
misquoting Einstein and start understanding what he actually meant.﻿

comments.text:
Interesting concept - "8-bit Science". Nice job, and nice job summarizing 
Nitchze (thought I'd take a stab at spelling it without looking), he who 
said:
"Science cannot 'explain' the world (the 'why'), only 'describe' it (the 
'how')."
"God is dead."
"Science has no consideration for ultimate purposes."
"People worship science as a kind of 'new religion' - an objective value 
for a godless age."
"Man shouldn't be the servant of knowledge, knowledge should be the servant 
of man."

One thing he got wrong was the 'why' and 'how' - science correctly 
addresses the 'how', for the answer to 'why' is always "because the 
universe is a chaos system".

As for ultimate purpose (for example, preserving higher consciousness 
against a harsh universe) and the value of science itself (is knowledge a 
good thing or not), not to mention answering core life questions like, "Why 
bother?" these also fall under the realm of philosophy - though philosophy 
has dropped the ball of late, to the point of Stephen Hawking writing, 
"Philosophy is Dead" - and he is right, but only currently - it can be 
resurrected - it only needs to find itself again).

To answer the title's question, good science can 'discover' reality (for 
science is a mere part of reality, and does not equal it) (engineering can 
protect us from it, to note), but bad science is tainted - sometimes by 
make-believe and politics; and sometimes by errant ambition, face-saving, 
and pet theories - bad science does not reflect reality..

A note on theoretical science: this is completely different, and it is here 
where anti-science sentiments arise - for on the edge, models of reality 
are still developing, and are thus still arguable (which the argumentative 
latch on to). If a theory stand up to penetrating questions and tests, and, 
best case, can be used to make predictions, then it is deemed 'adequate' 
(for no model can ever be 'complete'), and it remains 'useful' until a more 
accurate model comes along (based on new knowledge, or more rare, a better 
interpretation) that can stand up to new questions and tests.﻿

comments.author: james Last

comments.text:
God I hate Nietzsche.
His entire argument here, as well as in many of his other works, is 
completely based on a trivial bit of wordplay (Explain vs. Describe, How 
vs. Why, etc.).

He is attempting to undermine what we consider as truth merely by attacking 
the fundamental aspects of that understand, which, in its own right, is a 
healthy philosophical practice, and not one which should be thrown out 
wholesale.  However, there is difference between good fundamental criticism 
and useless criticism.

For instance, questioning the existence of a God, whether morals are 
objective, or the relativistic importance of an issue is good fundamental 
criticism.  It allows us to better find the point from which further study 
and debate may begin.  Questions like these grant the philosopher an axiom 
on which to build further.

But, when looking at Nietzche's attack, we see that all he has done is 
confound the matter without approaching the truly important issue.  Instead 
of asking whether science has purpose (as he assumes religion does; which 
science does, btw), it would be far better to ask whether knowledge and 
wisdom can amount to any meaning or purpose whatsoever.

Does the world have meaning?  Can knowledge be purely objective?  If 
science could achieve such an end (pure, objective, universal meaning), is 
it one we should necessarily pursue?

Instead of getting the man's opinions on these matters, we get this mundane 
BS.
That said, I do really like Nietzsche's "Parable of a Madman", so, he's got 
that going for him, which is nice.﻿

comments.text:
I am not saying I subscribe to Nietzsche's morality.. I was just clarifying 
what his position would be.

I also reject Kant's morality, which claims universals.

Morality is subject to social norms... that doesn't make it right or 
wrong.. it is just a fluid state of reasoning and judgement.

We can't say anything is UNIVERSALLY good or bad... there's always some 
exception based on the instance.

There's the Trolly thought experiement and Jon in South America... 

The difficult morality behind choosing to let or kill some to save many.

Universals say "never do it," and though I agree to that.. exceptions exist 
in that for every society.

I can kill to save myself... I can kill to save my child.

So how then is it a universal if we apply conditions to it?

If we say "you can never kill" you end up in a moral dilemna of how to save 
someone who is going to be killed unjustly?

Should you kill one to save the other?

It seems an easy yes, but then you have denied the universal.. and made it 
conditional.

This is a more complicated subject than many Existentialists ever tackle...

Sartre is better at it than Nietzsche...

But this is all very OLD Philosophy... Nietzsche is important for his 
denial of social norms... encouraging people to break from the rank and 
file and pursue their own interests.

If you do so and come up against violent backlash... you did it wrong, 
that's all Nietzsche says.

Don't conform to society, but don't anger it against your life either...

Nietzsche hates Martyrs... they are weak.

Survival is strength.

Again.. it's a complicated topic with Nietzsche as he's quite subtle and 
even sarcastic (I think of Bacon and Socrates personally... but a raging 
asshole).

Nietzsche's Infinite Horizon is his wording for the possiblities of life 
when you brush "god" aside as a moral compass... mostly because it has 
failed on many occasions...

The "universals" the Bible claims are weak... they don't work.. and can 
even contradict themselves. (See George Carlin Commandments).

Nietzsche is both the End of the Modern Era and the Beginning of the 
Contemporary Era of Philosophy.. he is an important bridge of thought...

he is not someone to follow blindly.

That goes against Nietzsche's very teaching...

To be yourself.  -_-

I am not as familiar with works of Nietzsche to comment on that. "Science 
cannot *prove the existence of* the ultimate purpose" is not a meaningless 
statement, although I would like to see the argument for why is that the 
case. However, "Science cannot *tell* us what  the ultimate purpose *is*", 
is a meaningless statement, since it presumes the existence of the ultimate 
purpose, which hasn't been proven in the first place. If one day the 
ultimate purpose is proven to exist then the second statement could become 
not meaningless, but until then it is.

Once again, he was not arguing that there IS a higher purpose, but that 
people want there to be or think there is. Science does not give any idea 
of a higher purpose because that is not its point, it is to describe how 
things work in our world and universe. But to why, as in, why does it do 
that, why does it form such shape, the ultimate purpose of why any of this 
exists, you won't get a answer(Yes I know you can tell me all the chemicals 
and numbers and all that to "why" but all your doing is explaining 
something not asking why). Just because you deny any idea of a higher 
purpose does not mean or negate anyone who thinks there is, for what you 
observe is not the same as what everyone observes.

For example, we all see the sky blue. Science will tell us the details of 
why that is. But to some people, they are color blind, or purely blind, and 
thus cannot see this color. Are they right to not believe us simply cause 
they cannot see what we do?

You can accept that science is just a tool for describing and understanding 
the how tos of the universe but not able to answer the why, or you can keep 
repeating the same point over and over again without truly opening your 
mind to the multiple possibilities.

comments.text:
This video misses several key points.

First: It assumes that the universe HAS meaning, that searching for 
meaning--rather than making meaning--is a worthwhile endeavor.
Meaning may be something humanity wants...but it may not be something 
humanity can have because it may not exist.

Second: When it talks about evangelizing science, and then gives examples, 
what it's showing is the difference between science which has basis in 
demonstrable fact...and religion "just saying so". The latter is 
evangelizing, to be sure...but the former is doing nothing of the kind; it 
is simply stating what we know to be so after rigorous research and 
testing, presumably in the face of because-god-says-so opposition.
The comparisons given in the video are apples and oranges, yet the maker of 
the vid does not appear to recognize this.

Third: At the end, the video pulls a kind of switcheroo, changing from 
"science" to "knowledge", and then telling us to be critical of both...yet 
the very nature of science, of science when it is done properly, is to be 
critical of everything. Even well-established theories, even facts thought 
to be well-understood, are subject to revision; science quite often tells 
us that what we know is wrong.

Whether the video is intentionally misleading or unintentionally mistaken, 
I find that it is somewhat off-base and misses the point.﻿

comments.text:
I like this series but not this video. It seems like the point is, science 
isn't perfect and can't answer everything, so science isn't the truth - 
just like religion. And we should talk about these things on equal footing.

I completely disagree with that. Science is the closest thing to truth that 
there is. The video argues it can't get to the "why", but it can very well. 
Why does fire burn? Chemical properties. Why are the chemical properties 
the way they are? The composition of the molecules and atoms affecting 
electronegativities and bonding interactions that release energy with the 
change. Why are do the atoms have the electronegativities that they do? The 
structure of the atom, number of protons and neutrons. Why? We can get into 
subatomic physics. Why? We can delve deeper. But yeah, eventually we don't 
know. Why did the big bang happen? We're working on figuring that out, but 
even if we do, do you think people won't ask why whatever that answer is 
happened? What caused whatever caused the big bang? Science not having 
every answer does not mean you can put it on equal footing with religion 
when you're talking about truth.﻿

is, is meaningless.  It assumes that a reason exists.  That's an unfounded 
assumption.  Since we have good reason to think that meaning only exists in 
the brain, as an idea, we therefore have good reason to think that there is 
no reason why fire is the way it is.  And, also, that science can indeed 
explain meaning.   It just has to explain how thoughts are formed in the 
brain, how the brain evolved, etc.﻿

comments.author: TechnocraticBushman

comments.text:
+Adam Ursell Forgot to metion one thing. Scientists know this well. We do 
live in a cave. And so, we've developed tools to see past the shadows. Take 
the shadows allegory. Shadows are 2d monochrome projections of a 3d world. 
Well based on Einstein's infamous equation we know for a fact that space 
has 4 dimensions (at least, if you discard the string theory which is no 
theory at all). We've already measured this. Relative to the keyboard in 
front of you, you travel in time at the speed of light. Were you to move in 
space relatively to it, you would start to stagnate in time and travel in 
space. And when you approach the speed of light in space, time 
stops(relatively to the keyboard). So our 3d world is a projection, an 
illusion, a shadow of the real world. We don't take into account relativity 
as we're simply not that fast. But were it not true, GPS technology would 
not work. So that's why the scientific method was developed. It is a tool 
to coming ever closer to the truth without fooling ourselves. Philosophers 
usually describe all possible worlds but it's the scientist's job to 
discover which of the many possibilities actually applies to the one we 
live in. Whenever say someone says "maybe there is no dark energy. 
gravitation is repulsive over large distances", that's philosophy or rather 
metaphysics. If we create an experiment and demonstrate this to hold true, 
then it's science.

Science can tell you about the tangible properties of a thing but it can't 
tell you what to do about it. Anyone who thinks otherwise should look up 
the Naturalistic Fallacy. 

Let's say science says humans can't run a mile under 4 minutes because the 
bones can't handle it, a real thought prior to Roger Bannister breaking it. 

Let's say observations thus far say humans can't stay awake, and perform 
difficult activities for a week straight. Well every man who has ever 
passed the SEAL's Hell Week would contradict that.

Science is a collection of averages. Science is arbitrary data points. 
Science is not an ethical compass or a predictor of the future.
